cards.title: Dhaka Slum Inferno Leaves Thousands Homeless As 1,500 Shanties Collapse Into Ash And Twisted Rubble
cards.abstract: A massive inferno consumed the Korail slum in Dhaka, burning or damaging 1,500 homes and rendering thousands homeless within hours. The fire exposed Bangladesh’s fragile urban infrastructure, leaving vulnerable communities, many of them climate migrants, with nowhere to go. Firefighters battled the flames for 16 hours but narrow alleys hindered rescue efforts. As smoke rose over Dhaka’s richest districts, survivors scavenged through the rubble for valuables, mourning the collapse of entire communities in one night. This tragedy reflects the harsh reality facing millions who live on the edge of poverty in one of the world’s most densely populated cities.

cards.title: India's Updated Quake Map Warns Entire Himalayan Arc Faces Major Risk, Forcing Urgent Safety Reforms
cards.abstract: India’s new seismic zonation map has rewritten the nation’s earthquake risk profile by elevating the entire Himalayan corridor into the highest danger Zone VI. Experts say the shift corrects decades of underestimation of the central Himalayan segment, where locked faults continue accumulating stress powerful enough to generate a massive surface-rupturing earthquake. Using global PSHA standards, the updated Earthquake Design Code integrates active faults, maximum magnitudes, soil behaviour, near-fault motion and exposure-based vulnerability. As a result, 61% of India’s land is now officially under moderate to high seismic hazard. The fresh norms introduce strict requirements for buildings, focusing for the first time on non-structural failures that often cause injuries. Critical infrastructure must stay operational even after severe shaking. This map is a blueprint for survival, forcing India to confront its most dangerous natural threat.

images.title: India's Updated Quake Map Warns Entire Himalayan Arc Faces Major Risk, Forcing Urgent Safety Reforms
